subject: Re: QS news update
msgSnippet: An Australian can read an American QS text and vise versa because they are sufficiently similar, but not because they are identical. They will never be
messageBody:
An Australian can read an American QS text and vise versa because they
are sufficiently similar, but not because they are identical. They
will never be identical I fear.

Lexical sets will reduce a few of the problems that a fixed set of
phonemes has. But there is no way to train a person to use the letters
Ah, Awe and Ox correctly if he can not even hear the difference
between them. No way short of creating a single dictionary of all QS
words spelled out in the one and only allowable way. And this would
imply there is a single correct accent and that words are not
pronounced as they are spelled which is to say, just another TO with
letters that look different.

I know the goal might be to produce something like Spanish with it's
universal spelling, phonemic letters and huge variety of accents. But
this can not be done with English in its current state. The various
accents have evolved in an incompatible manner over the centuries
because the language was insufficiently phonetic to begin with.

In spite of this, QS is infinitely better than existing traditional
orthodoxy. And lexical sets have been of some help:

- Everyone will use #28 to spell "dress": this hasn't changed since
the lexical set discussion started.
- Everyone will use #29 to spell "face": this is a result of lexical sets.
- "bath" will still be spelled with two different letters depending on
your accent.
- "cloth" will still be spelled with three.
etc


--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Paul Tremblay <phthenry@...> wrote:
>
> Anthony Grahn wrote:
>
> > > So I want to use QS that is reasonable and readable for everyone.
> > >
> >
> > Just wondering: which accent are you trying to recreate?
> >
>
> My understanding is that lexical sets pretty much neutralize accents,
> no? I write "sit" with "If" as my vowel and hear it my own way; an
> Australian uses the same letter, though he hears a different sound. But
> we both can understand each other.
>
> If we are going to need different dictionaries for different accents,
> aren't we using something that is inferior to TO? The advantage with TO
> is that an Australian can pick up a novel written by an American and
> read it as quickly as if it were written by an Australian (with perhaps
> a few phrases he might not be aware of). If QS cannot reach across
> dialects in the same way, then it is inferior to TO, at least in this
> respect.
>
> At least the news might be bringing some of these issues to the surface
> so we can discuss them.
>
> Paul
>
